title: 107_s1656
content: The Act may be cited as the "Veterans Benefits Administration Improvement Act of 2001". The Veterans Benefits Administration is responsible for processing claims for veterans compensation and pension. Concerns have been raised about the accuracy of claims processing, despite reported high accuracy rates. The Veterans Benefits Administration reported a 64 percent accuracy rate in processing claims in 1998 and 2000, lower than the previously reported 95 percent accuracy rate. Adequate training for claims adjudicators is crucial as the administration may lose up to 30 percent of its workforce to retirement by 2003. The Veterans Benefits Administration needs to ensure efficient processing of veterans' claims as 30 percent of its workforce may retire by 2003. Adequate training for claims adjudicators is crucial to avoid delays in providing compensation and pension benefits. The expected appeals processing time for a claim in 2001 is 621 days. Delays in providing veterans with compensation and pension benefits are a concern. In 2001, the expected appeals processing time for a claim was 621 days, and the backlog of pending work at the Veterans Benefits Administration was 533,029 claims. Improvement of processing of veterans benefits claims. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a plan within 90 days of this Act's enactment to improve the processing of veterans' compensation and pension claims. The plan should focus on enhancing training for claims adjudicators and employee accountability standards to ensure thorough initial reviews of claims. The plan must include mechanisms for improving training of claims adjudicators, enhancing employee accountability standards, and avoiding unnecessary appeals and delays in benefit payments. It should also strengthen the Veterans Benefits Administration's ability to identify recurring errors in claims adjudications through better data collection and management. The Veterans Benefits Administration aims to improve data collection and management to identify common errors in disability and pension claims, as well as deficiencies in medical evidence. They plan to implement a system for reviewing claims processing accuracy that meets federal standards for internal control and organizational independence. The Veterans Benefits Administration plans to implement mechanisms for evaluating the impact of the Training and Performance Support System on claims processing accuracy and consistency, with quantifiable goals for each mechanism. The Secretary will consult with veterans organizations and other stakeholders in developing the plan. The Secretary will consult with veterans organizations and stakeholders to develop a plan for implementing mechanisms to evaluate the impact of the Training and Performance Support System on claims processing accuracy. The plan will be implemented 60 days after submission and can be modified with a 30-day notice to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary may modify the plan submitted under subsection (a) with a 30-day notice to relevant committees. Reports on the plan's progress must be submitted every six months to specified parties. The Secretary must submit reports every six months to specified parties assessing the implementation of the plan and whether goals are being achieved. Funding for the plan will come from appropriations for the Veterans Benefits Administration.
